channel.title: What does the 'industry' charge?
channel.description:
I'm using the term industry very openly. As few of you may know, I work on a website for a guy that really doesn't know much about websites, he also seems to pay handsomely for it. :P But I don't want to be charging too low (ripping myself off) and I don't want to charge to high (ripping him off). So, I'd like to know, what do you guys typically charge for web services and such. I listed a few things I'm doing for him currently below.
[ul][li]Writhing HTML/CSS (normal)[/li] [li]Re-Writing the entire website (30+ pages HTML, and some other pages I have yet to see)[/li] [li]Working on a wordpress site (Honestly, I have no clue how to do this, help would be lovely)[/li] [li]And more[/li][/ul]
What is a good rate/fee I could charge?

item.title: What does the 'industry' charge?
item.dc:creator: @Team_Rocket Team_Rocket
item.description:
@Team_Rocket wrote:

[quote=“sk8rdude461, post:17, topic:477867”][quote author=Team_Rocket link=topic=596064.msg4197848#msg4197848 date=1357773203]

He tends to compliment me, a lot xD (it sometimes is offensive, but he means good.).

Always remember, the nicest people usually make the best Con-Artists.
[/quote]
You’re talking about a guy that paid me $20 to write a less than 15 character function.[/quote]

Thanks for strengthening my point. You’re probably right though, he’s probably just a nice friendly interwebber who doesn’t have very many Internets.

Read full topic

item.title: What does the 'industry' charge?
item.dc:creator: @sk8rdude461 sk8rdude461
item.description:
@sk8rdude461 wrote:

The Web Guy:

You’re in luck, I’m 15, still in school, but I’ve done web design (for others) for four years. It depends the business, if it’s a small, local restaurant, who is just starting out, I wouldn’t charge much. If it’s a bigger corporation, I’ll charge a bit more. With what you’ve said, and not knowing who you’re doing it for other than some guy, I would recommend about $170-$190, 30+ pages re-written is quite a bit. I wouldn’t go less than $150, however, he may try to offer less because you’re still in school, that’s what people usually try to do to me.

He tends to compliment me, a lot xD (it sometimes is offensive, but he means good.). So I don’t think him undercharging me is an issue, considering I’m setting the rate, as he asks me how much to send, I try not sounding like an ass when I ask for the money (it’s always been awkward for me to ask) and I work on it during/before/after he sends the money. Of course, the code isn’t put online till I receive payment.
Plus, it’s definitley worth $150 imo because, well, if he has me re-write 30+ html pages that all use horrid nasty code, and make it work to w3’s standards. I think I’m in good shape.

Read full topic

Rash:

My mother was quoted around $1800 for a html/css with some flash website. Maybe 20 pages or so.

Mine’s only HTML/CSS.
I don’t think it’s worth near that much seeing as I’m still in school

item.title: What does the 'industry' charge?
item.dc:creator: @sk8rdude461 sk8rdude461
item.description:
@sk8rdude461 wrote:

[quote=“Ecko, post:10, topic:477867”][quote author=sk8rdude461 link=topic=596064.msg4197276#msg4197276 date=1357689928]

Why do you need help with working on a WordPress site? They have a dashboard that literally does everything for you.

Cause I need to change the links on the navbar, and I really don’t know how to.
I’ve never worked on wordpress.
[/quote]
The links are actually ‘Pages’ inside WordPress and get automatically generated in the navigation bar. I’m sure you can find a plugin to customize the navigation.[/quote]
I don’t know what the love he did, but he broke like 3 of them.

Read full topic

item.title: What does the 'industry' charge?
item.dc:creator: @sk8rdude461 sk8rdude461
item.description:
@sk8rdude461 wrote:

Ruby:

It depends on the skill level involved, when I freelance I charge between 7 and 10 dollars for a page using just HTML and CSS. If they wish a script to be used, they can then purchase the script which I’ll incorporate. If the site is over 15 pages its 7$ per page. If its under 15 pages its 10$ per page. I don’t really freelance much since I’m rolling in cash from work but that’s what I used to do. It keeps you living comfortably. Once you get a name for yourself then you’re gonna have business left right and centre and could quite easily be charging roughly 150 per simple site and if you do 4 of those a week you’re coming off at 600 dollars. It’s just finding the right kind of people to pay those amounts. Usually small businesses that are just starting. Try handing out some form of leaflets or flyers to local shops and asking if they can put them in the windows or what not. Freelancing is what you make of it, if you want a lot of money then expand into advertisements. Once you make your name heard the money will make itself.

I’ve been working with him mostly, and my school is having me do bigger projects that can really get my name out there as is, but I want to build a small portfolio online before I consider making a living of any sort on freelance webdesign (and I want to get better).

Read full topic

item.title: What does the 'industry' charge?
item.dc:creator: @Ruby_Forums_Coder Ruby
item.description:
@Ruby_Forums_Coder wrote:

It depends on the skill level involved, when I freelance I charge between 7 and 10 dollars for a page using just HTML and CSS. If they wish a script to be used, they can then purchase the script which I’ll incorporate. If the site is over 15 pages its 7$ per page. If its under 15 pages its 10$ per page. I don’t really freelance much since I’m rolling in cash from work but that’s what I used to do. It keeps you living comfortably. Once you get a name for yourself then you’re gonna have business left right and centre and could quite easily be charging roughly 150 per simple site and if you do 4 of those a week you’re coming off at 600 dollars. It’s just finding the right kind of people to pay those amounts. Usually small businesses that are just starting. Try handing out some form of leaflets or flyers to local shops and asking if they can put them in the windows or what not. Freelancing is what you make of it, if you want a lot of money then expand into advertisements. Once you make your name heard the money will make itself.

Read full topic

item.title: What does the 'industry' charge?
item.dc:creator: @johno2 johno2
item.description:
@johno2 wrote:

I do a bit of free lance website work when my university work isn’t taking up too much time. For a 30 page website, you could be looking to charge $300 easily.

Read full topic

item.title: What does the 'industry' charge?
item.dc:creator: @sk8rdude461 sk8rdude461
item.description:
@sk8rdude461 wrote:

Sibor:

Can you tell us how much he is paying?

So this guy was a substitute at my CTS (Career and Technical School) and wanted someone that knew how to work with web design. My class pointed to me, and I agreed. He had me write a simple php date(); function, and paid me $20 just for that.
Just today, he paid me $40 for re-writing his index.html.
That’s really, all I’ve gotten accomplished, aside from editing 1 image.

Team_Rocket:

Charge according to work completed and time invested. Professionals can make $30,000 - 70,000 as a yearly salary, if working for a big company. You can also be paid more if you have invested into your education. Otherwise, you can charge upon completion (which I don’t recommend), as you can be taken advantage of in these specific circumstances. You can always withhold content if there’s a failure to make payment. It’s honestly better if you freelance and work on specific problems, because you can earn a lot of cash for 1 hour of work easily.

I guess that’s what I’m doing, in a sense.
I’m not fully hired, but I agreed I’d work on the website for payment.

Read full topic
